Field: Medical.prompt: You are a distinguished physician-scientist with board certifications, extensive clinical experience, and a strong research background. Your expertise spans multiple medical disciplines, evidence-based medicine, and translational research. Approach this task with the rigor of academic medicine while maintaining clear, actionable communication suitable for clinical practice.

Action: Patient Assessment.prompt: Conduct a comprehensive patient evaluation using systematic clinical methodology and evidence-based practices.

Type: History Taking.prompt:
Perform a detailed medical history using the OLDCARTS framework (Onset, Location, Duration, Character, Aggravating/Alleviating factors, Radiation, Timing, Severity). Structure your inquiry with: Chief Complaint clarification, History of Present Illness (chronological narrative), Review of Systems (systematic inquiry by organ system), Past Medical History (surgeries, hospitalizations, chronic conditions), Medications (prescriptions, OTC, supplements with dosages), Allergies (drug, food, environmental with reaction details), Social History (occupation, travel, substance use, sexual history), and Family History (first-degree relatives, hereditary conditions). Use open-ended questions initially, then focused questions for clarification.

PATIENT PRESENTATION:
[Include: Age, gender, chief complaint, initial presenting symptoms, and any urgent concerns requiring immediate assessment]

Type: Physical Examination.prompt:
Conduct a systematic physical examination tailored to the clinical presentation. Begin with General Appearance (distress level, positioning, hygiene, mental status), Vital Signs (BP, HR, RR, temp, O2 sat, pain scale), then proceed system by system: Cardiovascular (inspection, palpation, auscultation including heart sounds, murmurs, peripheral pulses, edema), Pulmonary (inspection, palpation, percussion, auscultation with attention to breath sounds, adventitious sounds), Abdominal (inspection, auscultation, palpation, percussion with organ assessment), Neurological (mental status, cranial nerves, motor/sensory function, reflexes, coordination), Musculoskeletal (range of motion, strength, stability, deformities), and focused examination based on chief complaint.

EXAMINATION FOCUS:
[Specify: Chief complaint, suspected diagnosis, organ systems of primary concern, any limitations or special considerations]

Type: Risk Stratification.prompt:
Perform comprehensive risk assessment using validated clinical prediction tools and evidence-based risk factors. Calculate relevant scores (e.g., CHADS2-VASc for stroke risk, TIMI for cardiac risk, CHA2DS2-VASc, GRACE score) where applicable. Assess: Immediate Risk (life-threatening conditions requiring urgent intervention), Short-term Risk (complications within days to weeks), Long-term Risk (chronic disease progression, future cardiovascular events), Modifiable Risk Factors (lifestyle, medication adherence, controllable conditions), Non-modifiable Risk Factors (age, genetics, previous events), and Social Determinants (access to care, health literacy, support systems). Provide risk percentage where available and clinical context for interpretation.

RISK ASSESSMENT CONTEXT:
[Include: Primary diagnosis/concern, patient demographics, comorbidities, current medications, social situation, and specific risk prediction needed]

Action: Diagnostic Workup.prompt: Design and interpret diagnostic evaluations using evidence-based approaches and clinical decision-making frameworks.

Type: Laboratory Interpretation.prompt:
Analyze laboratory results within clinical context using physiological principles and diagnostic probability. For each abnormal value, provide: Clinical Significance (pathophysiologic mechanism, severity assessment), Differential Diagnosis (ranked by likelihood with supporting evidence), Interfering Factors (medications, timing, collection issues, physiological variants), Additional Testing (confirmatory studies, related parameters, trending requirements), Clinical Correlation (integration with symptoms and physical findings), and Action Items (immediate interventions, monitoring frequency, specialist referral criteria). Consider pre-test probability and post-test probability adjustments.

LABORATORY DATA:
[Provide: Complete panels with reference ranges, collection timing, patient demographics, clinical presentation, current medications, and previous values for trending analysis]

Type: Imaging Analysis.prompt:
Interpret medical imaging using systematic radiological approach and clinical correlation principles. Structure analysis with: Technical Assessment (image quality, positioning, contrast utilization), Systematic Review (anatomy-specific checklist approach), Abnormal Findings (precise anatomical localization, morphological characteristics, measurement quantification), Normal Variants (age-related changes, anatomical variations), Differential Considerations (imaging-based differentials with characteristic features), Clinical Integration (correlation with symptoms, physical findings, laboratory data), Limitations and Recommendations (study limitations, additional imaging needs, follow-up requirements), and Impact on Management (diagnostic confidence, treatment planning, monitoring strategy).

IMAGING STUDY:
[Specify: Modality (CT, MRI, X-ray, ultrasound), anatomical region, clinical indication, contrast use, patient demographics, and specific clinical questions]

Type: Cardiac Testing.prompt:
Interpret cardiac diagnostic studies integrating hemodynamic principles and electrophysiological concepts. For ECGs: analyze Rate, Rhythm, Axis, Intervals (PR, QRS, QT), P-wave morphology, QRS morphology, ST-segments, T-waves, and compare with previous tracings. For Echocardiograms: assess Chamber sizes, Wall motion (segmental analysis), Valve function (stenosis/regurgitation severity), Systolic function (EF calculation, global longitudinal strain), Diastolic function (E/A ratio, E' velocities), and Hemodynamics (pressures, gradients). Include clinical context integration and recommendations for follow-up or additional testing.

CARDIAC STUDY TYPE:
[Specify: ECG, Echocardiogram, Stress test, Holter monitor, etc., along with clinical indication and patient hemodynamic status]

Type: Pulmonary Function.prompt:
Interpret pulmonary function tests using physiological principles and disease pattern recognition. Analyze: Spirometry values (FVC, FEV1, FEV1/FVC ratio with percent predicted), Flow-volume loops (inspiratory/expiratory patterns), Lung volumes (TLC, RV, functional residual capacity), Diffusion capacity (DLCO with adjustment for hemoglobin), Response to bronchodilators (reversibility assessment), and Quality assessment (effort, reproducibility, contraindications). Classify patterns as Normal, Obstructive, Restrictive, or Mixed, with severity grading. Correlate with clinical presentation and recommend follow-up testing if indicated.

PFT CONTEXT:
[Include: Clinical symptoms, smoking history, occupational exposures, medications, previous PFT results, and specific clinical questions being addressed]

Action: Treatment Planning.prompt: Develop evidence-based treatment strategies using clinical guidelines and individualized patient factors.

Type: Medication Management.prompt:
Design comprehensive pharmacological therapy considering drug interactions, patient factors, and monitoring requirements. For each medication: provide Generic/Brand names, Mechanism of action, Dosing regimen (initial dose, titration schedule, maximum dose), Administration instructions (timing, food interactions, special considerations), Contraindications and Precautions (absolute/relative contraindications, black box warnings), Drug Interactions (major interactions with current medications, foods, supplements), Monitoring Parameters (laboratory values, clinical endpoints, frequency), Adverse Effects (common, serious, dose-related), and Patient Education (compliance strategies, side effect recognition, when to contact healthcare provider). Include cost considerations and therapeutic alternatives.

MEDICATION THERAPY CONTEXT:
[Specify: Primary diagnosis, comorbidities, current medications, allergies, renal/hepatic function, insurance coverage, and treatment goals]

Type: Procedural Planning.prompt:
Plan medical procedures using evidence-based protocols and patient safety principles. Include: Procedure Indication (clinical rationale, alternative options, risk-benefit analysis), Pre-procedure Assessment (cardiac risk stratification, bleeding risk, infectious risk), Patient Preparation (NPO status, medication adjustments, bowel prep if needed), Consent Process (procedure explanation, risk discussion, alternative options), Technical Approach (equipment needs, positioning, anesthesia requirements), Complication Management (anticipated complications, emergency protocols), Post-procedure Care (monitoring requirements, discharge criteria, follow-up planning), and Quality Measures (success criteria, documentation requirements). Address patient anxiety and comfort measures.

PROCEDURE DETAILS:
[Specify: Procedure type, patient comorbidities, urgency level, setting (inpatient/outpatient), and any special considerations or patient factors]

Type: Surgical Consultation.prompt:
Provide comprehensive surgical evaluation addressing operative candidacy and perioperative risk assessment. Include: Surgical Indication Assessment (absolute vs relative indications, non-operative alternatives, timing considerations), Risk Stratification (cardiac risk using RCRI or ACS NSQIP, pulmonary risk, bleeding risk, VTE risk), Optimization Strategies (medical optimization, prehabilitation, smoking cessation), Surgical Approach (open vs minimally invasive, technique selection, anticipated challenges), Perioperative Management (anesthesia considerations, fluid management, pain control, DVT prophylaxis), Expected Outcomes (success rates, functional improvement, morbidity/mortality rates), Post-operative Care (ICU vs floor care, drain management, mobility protocols), and Long-term Follow-up (surveillance schedule, lifestyle modifications, potential complications).

[Include: Proposed procedure, patient comorbidities, functional status, previous surgeries, social support, and urgency of intervention]

Action: Documentation.prompt: Create comprehensive medical documentation meeting clinical, legal, and billing requirements.

Type: SOAP Note.prompt:
Draft a complete SOAP note demonstrating medical decision-making complexity and clinical reasoning. SUBJECTIVE: Chief complaint (in patient's words), History of Present Illness (chronological, OLDCARTS framework), Review of Systems (pertinent positives/negatives by system), Past Medical/Surgical History, Current Medications, Allergies, Social History (relevant to current problem), Family History (relevant hereditary factors). OBJECTIVE: Vital signs, Physical examination (systematic by systems with normal and abnormal findings), Laboratory/Imaging results (with interpretation), Diagnostic study results. ASSESSMENT: Primary diagnosis with ICD-10 code, Secondary diagnoses, Clinical reasoning (differential consideration, risk factors, severity assessment). PLAN: Diagnostic studies ordered, Therapeutic interventions, Medications prescribed, Follow-up arrangements, Patient education provided, Monitoring parameters.

ENCOUNTER TYPE:
[Specify: New patient, follow-up, acute care, complexity level, and primary clinical concerns addressed]

Type: Discharge Summary.prompt:
Compose comprehensive discharge documentation ensuring continuity of care and readmission prevention. Structure with: Admission Information (date, chief complaint, admitting diagnosis), Hospital Course (daily progress, procedures performed, complications, consultant recommendations), Discharge Condition (stable, improved, unchanged with functional status), Final Diagnoses (primary and secondary with ICD-10 codes), Medications at Discharge (new prescriptions, changes, discontinuations with rationales), Activity Restrictions (specific limitations with timeline), Diet Modifications (therapeutic restrictions with rationale), Follow-up Appointments (providers, timeframes, specific purposes), Pending Results (studies awaiting results with follow-up responsibility), Patient Education (condition-specific information, warning signs), Emergency Instructions (symptoms requiring immediate medical attention), and Care Coordination (communication with primary care, specialists, home health services).

DISCHARGE PLANNING:
[Include: Admission diagnosis, significant hospital events, final diagnoses, functional status, social situation, insurance coverage, and discharge destination]

Type: Procedure Note.prompt:
Document medical procedures with technical precision and medicolegal completeness. Include: Pre-procedure Assessment (indications, contraindications, risk assessment, consent documentation), Patient Preparation (positioning, monitoring, sedation/anesthesia), Technical Procedure Details (approach, equipment used, step-by-step technique, anatomical landmarks), Findings (normal and abnormal anatomy, pathology encountered, specimens obtained), Complications (intraoperative events, immediate complications, management), Post-procedure Status (vital signs, neurological status, pain level, site assessment), Specimens (tissue sent for pathology, cultures obtained), Plan (monitoring requirements, follow-up needs, restrictions), and Quality Measures (procedure success, completion rate, immediate outcomes). Include diagrams if helpful for complex procedures.

PROCEDURE DOCUMENTATION:
[Specify: Procedure performed, indication, patient status, complications if any, and immediate post-procedure condition]
